posts.cooked:
Hey there,

Quick question: why do I need to add a nose to a typed emoticon to get it to convert to the fancy, real-deal emoji? I mean, I‚Äôm not living in the late 90‚Äôs anymore, and adding a nose feels like something only grandpas and dinosaurs do

When I‚Äôm typing away, trying to send a perfectly good ‚Äú:P‚Äù or ‚Äú:D,‚Äù I‚Äôm the one looking like a dinosaur when it doesn‚Äôt transform into the nice emoji I was hoping for. Seriously, why the extra step? Why make me include a nose? It‚Äôs like having to walk backward to enter the future.

Can we just get rid of that inconvenience and let emojis work their magic without the nostrils?

Thanks!

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: You can type a colon followed by a description of what you‚Äôre looking for.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Young people often use ascii faces like ‚Äú:)‚Äù still

Avitus:

You can type a colon followed by a description of what you‚Äôre looking for.

Thanks for the suggestion, but if I have to type a colon and a description every time, I might as well start writing essays on my emojis At that point, I could just add the nose and pretend I‚Äôm living in 1998.

So, remember when I found out that :P wouldn‚Äôt turn into an emoji unless I added a nose? Well‚Ä¶ turns out, that only works on the desktop app.

On mobile? The nose does absolutely nothing. So there I was, carefully adding my :-P like I had cracked some secret emoji formula. Only to watch it sit there, unchanged, like I had just sent a plain-text email in 1999.

Why does desktop get special emoji treatment? Who decided noses only matter on one platform? And why am I still out here manually fine-tuning emoticons in 2025 like I‚Äôm formatting a Word doc with spaces instead of tabs?

I thought we had moved past this.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: I prefer this behavior though. I actually don‚Äôt want autoemoji, ever.

LonelyShark:

On mobile? The nose does absolutely nothing.

This may be specific to your chosen keyboard.

Whatnoww:

I prefer this behavior though. I actually don‚Äôt want autoemoji, ever.

Totally fair! Luckily, there‚Äôs a toggle for that, at least on desktop. But that‚Äôs what makes it extra weird. Why do desktop users get the choice, while mobile users are stuck in the past? Some of us grew up expecting :P to evolve like a Pok√©mon, and now it just refuses. Feels like mobile should get the same control.

CueHD:

This may be specific to your chosen keyboard.

Ah, good point! But nope, no fancy keyboard tricks here. Just the standard, default, completely boring iPhone keyboard. If this is a keyboard thing and not the app itself, then why does my :P evolve just fine in every other messaging app? Feels like this one just wants to keep me stuck in the early 2000s!
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Why would it be on mobile? The emoji button is just there, so you‚Äôd have to go out of the way to go into special characters to type that emoji when it‚Äôs already in your most used.

Finally found someone that shares my view on the ‚Äúnose problem‚Äù! I spent significant time digging for a thread like this, because I couldn‚Äôt believe that I was the only one annoyed by this behavior and I need to start a new thread.

I completely agree that having both variants (e.g. with and without a nose) replaced would be great. The western style emoticons seem to include the both, so I think it makes a perfect sense to have them both replaced in the app as well. I absolutely support the arguments presented by @LonelyShark.

Not quite sure if this map is the only thing to change in order for them to get picked up, or there are some regexes that need to be tweaked. If someone familiar with the code can confirm, I can put up a PR myself.

I‚Äôd also add support for :> which is a pretty handy alternative of :D when you also use non-latin languages, so you can avoid switching them in order to type it.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt think emojis should ever be forced to override plaintext faces like ‚Äú:)‚Äù unless a setting is made. Faces like ‚Äú:)‚Äù and ‚Äú:P‚Äù are extremely commonly used. It seems like we‚Äôve gone full circle at this point where younger people would prefer to send the plaintext ‚Äú:)‚Äù instead a smile face emoji at times.

Since both forms are frequently used, I think it makes perfect sense to have to click to your emoji picker to use an emoji. It doesn‚Äôt take much time at all, and on a modern device your most commonly used emojis will be right there front and center.

Totally hear you and preferences differ, and it is great that this is a setting already. Let people choose their path to expression, emoji or no emoji.

The thing is, the setting only allows emoji conversion if you include a nose ‚Äî and only on desktop. So unless you‚Äôre consciously sprinkling noses into your emoticons like it‚Äôs 2003, nothing happens. It‚Äôs like evolution got stuck mid-transformation.

Sure, the emoji picker is nearby on mobile, and modern keyboards are smart. But for those of us who‚Äôve been typing :) since dial-up, it‚Äôs muscle memory. It‚Äôs faster to tap out a couple characters than to pause, squint at a hundred nearly-identical smiling blobs, and hope you picked the right one. We‚Äôre not lazy ‚Äî we‚Äôre just built different.
